wing.title: Wing
body:
Wings create aerodynamic lift when moved forward (in the direction of the black decal). They are a more advanced version of CrudeWings. The lift force depends on the speed and size of the Wing. Thickness beyond 4 studs does not contribute to lift. Pitch the Wing up and down to control vertical speed.

Wings do not function inside other wings and break if subjected to extreme horizontal speeds.
wing.rawBody:
Wings create aerodynamic lift when moved forward (in the direction of the black decal). They
are a more advanced version of CrudeWings. The lift force depends on the speed and size of 
the Wing. Thickness beyond 4 studs does not contribute to lift. Pitch the Wing up and down 
to control vertical speed.

Wings do not function inside other wings and break if subjected to extreme horizontal speeds.

wire.title: Wire
body: Wires transmit energy between energy cells and loads such as Lights or Motors.
wire.rawBody: Wires transmit energy between energy cells and loads such as Lights or Motors.

wood.title: Wood
body:
Wood is a light, malleable, and cheap material obtained from trees. The main downside of Wood as a building material is the fact that it is flammable.

For use in a campfire, Wood should be made into Firewood, as it burns longer.
wood.rawBody:
Wood is a light, malleable, and cheap material obtained from trees. The main downside
of Wood as a building material is the fact that it is flammable.

For use in a campfire, Wood should be made into Firewood, as it burns longer.

zapwire.title: ZapWire
body:
ZapWires damage players and set fire to flammable parts on contact while powered. They will also signal signalable parts and briefly power energy-using parts.

In addition to glowing while powered, ZapWires also glow when signaled but have none of their contact effects when signaled instead of powered.

ZapWire Doors (DoorTemplate with ZapWire material) do not have any damaging effects but can still signal parts that are not locked by a different player.
zapwire.rawBody:
ZapWires damage players and set fire to flammable parts on contact while powered. They will
also signal signalable parts and briefly power energy-using parts.

In addition to glowing while powered, ZapWires also glow when signaled but have none of their 
contact effects when signaled instead of powered.

ZapWire Doors (DoorTemplate with ZapWire material) do not have any damaging effects but can 
still signal parts that are not locked by a different player.

footerData.name: Uses
footerData.desc: Weapon, Electronics, Fire Starter, Neon Signs

hammer.title: Hammer
body:
The Hammer tool enables advanced building features. It has 6 sub-tools:

-Dye: Paints parts. Hover over an object and press Q to pick the object's color. 
-Surface: Adds different surfaces to parts, such as hinges.
-Config: Configures properties of certain parts.
-Resize: Resizes parts, depending on their malleability.
-Size Copier: Can be used to rapidly set several parts to the same size.
-Link: Constraint Joint tool that can add 3 types of Constraints:
\*SpringConstraint: A customizable spring between two items.
\*RopeConstraint: A rope between two items that will not let them move too far apart.
When connected between Pipe, it becomes a Hose that can transfer substances. \*RodConstraint: A rigid rod between two items. When linked from a DriveBox to an
Engine, SteamEngine, Turbofan, or Motor, it will act as a driveshaft.
\*BallConstraint: A 360 degree pivot which joins the nearest edges of each part.
hammer.rawBody:
The Hammer tool enables advanced building features. It has 6 sub-tools:

-Dye: Paints parts. Hover over an object and press Q to pick the object's color. 
-Surface: Adds different surfaces to parts, such as hinges.
-Config: Configures properties of certain parts.
-Resize: Resizes parts, depending on their malleability.
-Size Copier: Can be used to rapidly set several parts to the same size.
-Link: Constraint Joint tool that can add 3 types of Constraints:
*SpringConstraint: A customizable spring between two items.
*RopeConstraint: A rope between two items that will not let them move too far apart.
When connected between Pipe, it becomes a Hose that can transfer substances.
*RodConstraint: A rigid rod between two items. When linked from a DriveBox to an
Engine, SteamEngine, Turbofan, or Motor, it will act as a driveshaft.
*BallConstraint: A 360 degree pivot which joins the nearest edges of each part.

sword.title: Sword
body: Swords are melee weapons useful against players and bots. They can also be used to quickly slice apart Balloons and Sails.
sword.rawBody:
Swords are melee weapons useful against players and bots. They can also be used to quickly 
slice apart Balloons and Sails.

biolab.title: BioLab
body:
The BioLab is a machine used for creating, engineering, and analyzing plants, as well as the production of certain substances.

A supply of organic substances are required for BioLab operations. Power the BioLab and insert Wood or Leaves to fill it. OrganicMatter as a part is often produced as a byproduct. When the bar is full, click "Generate New" to create a random new DNA profile, or insert a single Seed to copy its DNA profile.

The DNA profile screen shows the stat levels and traits of the plant. Click on a stat bar to increase it; this requires a small amount of organic supply, and tends to diminish the other stats when used. Click "Create Seed" to spawn a ready-to-plant seed with the corresponding DNA profile (requires organic supply). 

Click the TRAITS menu to swap a random trait with another random trait, if one is available. This costs organic supply, and does not remove/add rare or nutrient traits (Photosynth, Parasite, Fungus). Trait swapping also has a chance of removing a trait with no replacement.

**=====STATS=====**

H - Health: Reduces occurrences of plant death.
L - Longevity: Increases the average maximum age the plant can live.
R - Replication: Increases replication rate and range.
S - Size: Increases plant size and resistance to damaging effects.
G - Growth Rate: Speeds plant growth from seedling to fully grown.
T - Tolerance: Improves plant survivability at higher altitudes.

**=====TRAITS=====**

-Photosynth: Thrives in sunlight.
-Parasite: Thrives by leeching nutrients from other species in a wide radius.
-Fungus: Thrives covered from sunlight. Can grow on any relatively weak part.
-Seaworthy: Enables growth on the ocean.
-Flamer: Bursts into fireballs on impact.
-Toxic: Kills players on contact, and is converted to Toxin on contact with a Container.
-Blooming: Occasional bursts of rapid replication.
-Tough: Improved resistance to Herbicide and Herbicidal/Parasite plants.
-Exclusive: Cannot be analyzed or copied; players are unable to obtain Seeds.
-Mutator: Mutates more frequently.
-Herbicidal: Harms nearby plants of different species.
-Electric: Generates electricity into nearby energy cells.
-Wood: Wood can be obtained by harvesting.
-Cotton: Cotton can be obtained by harvesting.
-Superior: Bonus to all stats.
-Edible: Can be clicked to eat, healing the player (or harming if Toxic/Flamer/Popper).
-Thicket: Grows in tight clusters.
-Nexus: Vines connect between nearby plants, able to grow through walls.
-Stonecrop: Able to grow on mountains or other stone terrain.
-Capped: Stops replicating after 20 generations, and gives a bonus to all stats.
-Efficient: More likely to survive when resources are scarce (high plant count).
-Golden (RARE): Gold can be obtained by harvesting.
-Popper (RARE): Releases extremely destructive orgaballs on impact.
-Withering (RARE): Drains nutrients from nearby players, and powerful while doing so.

organicmatter.title: OrganicMatter
body: OrganicMatter is a byproduct organic material produced by the BioLab. Plants can grow on it, and is used for manufacturing a few other items.
organicmatter.rawBody:
OrganicMatter is a byproduct organic material produced by the BioLab. Plants can grow on
it, and is used for manufacturing a few other items.

footerData.name: Obtained
footerData.desc: Inserting Leaves or Wood into a BioLab, Nexus Plant Vines

herbicide.title: Herbicide
body:
Herbicide is a special bomb used to destroy Plants.

When signaled, it releases a large gas burst that is harmless to players, but eliminates all Plants within a 200-stud radius. Generated Cotton Plants are not affected. 

The range is reduced when used against plants with the Tough trait.
herbicide.rawBody:
Herbicide is a special bomb used to destroy Plants.

When signaled, it releases a large gas burst that is harmless to players, but eliminates
all Plants within a 200-stud radius. Generated Cotton Plants are not affected. 

The range is reduced when used against plants with the Tough trait.

clock.title: Clock
body:
A Clock keeps track of the current time and year (year is the red number). It requires no power to operate.

Each game hour (30-60 real life seconds), Clocks signal the current hour (0-23).
clock.rawBody:
A Clock keeps track of the current time and year (year is the red number). It requires no 
power to operate.

Each game hour (30-60 real life seconds), Clocks signal the current hour (0-23).

balloon.title: Balloon
body:
Balloons float in the air when activated.

Set the Balloon's height using a connected Controller. Lifting power is reduced as height increases. Balloons cannot safely be placed inside of each other.

The resiliency of Balloons is affected by their size; small or thin Balloons are easily destroyed, but large Balloons are more resistant. Damage allows hydrogen to leak out and causes the Balloon to lose buoyancy over time. Swords deal substantial damage to Balloons, especially on the ground. Balloons are also damaged if subjected to extreme horizontal speeds.
balloon.rawBody:
Balloons float in the air when activated.

Set the Balloon's height using a connected Controller. Lifting power is reduced as height
increases. Balloons cannot safely be placed inside of each other.

The resiliency of Balloons is affected by their size; small or thin Balloons are easily
destroyed, but large Balloons are more resistant. Damage allows hydrogen to leak out and 
causes the Balloon to lose buoyancy over time. Swords deal substantial damage to Balloons, 
especially on the ground. Balloons are also damaged if subjected to extreme horizontal 
speeds.

energyshield.title: EnergyShield
body:
EnergyShields generate a hollow barrier around themselves when powered, protecting the interior from most forms of attack but also preventing weapons from being fired out of it.

The shield will only generate successfully if there are no objects blocking the edges (except for terrain). If the shield generation fails, it will not be re-attempted for 30 seconds. Damage to the shield causes large spikes in power usage which can vary widely.

Paint the EnergyShield to change the shield's color. Use the Hammer's Config tool to set the shield radius. Power usage increases with radius.
energyshield.rawBody:
EnergyShields generate a hollow barrier around themselves when powered, protecting the interior
from most forms of attack but also preventing weapons from being fired out of it.

The shield will only generate successfully if there are no objects blocking the edges (except
for terrain). If the shield generation fails, it will not be re-attempted for 30 seconds. Damage 
to the shield causes large spikes in power usage which can vary widely.

Paint the EnergyShield to change the shield's color. Use the Hammer's Config tool to set the 
shield radius. Power usage increases with radius.

footerData.name: Recipe
footerData.desc: Copper, Diamond, Jade, Ruby, Uranium, Zaktralia

cloakingdevice.title: CloakingDevice
body:
The CloakingDevice, when powered, renders the machine connected to it invisible to sight, Radars, and Seekers.

CloakingDevices cannot cloak parts directly or indirectly connected to ground. CloakingDevices also cannot cloak objects that are more than 120 parts; however, they will be camoflauged for space.
cloakingdevice.rawBody:
The CloakingDevice, when powered, renders the machine connected to it invisible to sight,
Radars, and Seekers.

CloakingDevices cannot cloak parts directly or indirectly connected to ground. CloakingDevices 
also cannot cloak objects that are more than 120 parts; however, they will be camoflauged for
space.

footerData.desc: Glass, Gold, Jade, Ruby, Silicon, Zaktralia

delaywire.title: DelayWire
body:
The DelayWire will delay an incoming signal. They can be used to make simple timers for machines/bombs, or for capacitors that can store signals.

DelayWires will not signal other DelayWires that have been signaled sooner than their delay setting, so that strings of DelayWires won't feed back into each other.

Use the Config Tool to set the number of seconds to delay (up to 1800, or 30 minutes).
delaywire.rawBody:
The DelayWire will delay an incoming signal. They can be used to make simple timers
for machines/bombs, or for capacitors that can store signals.

DelayWires will not signal other DelayWires that have been signaled sooner than their delay 
setting, so that strings of DelayWires won't feed back into each other.

Use the Config Tool to set the number of seconds to delay (up to 1800, or 30 minutes).

corrosion.title: Corrosion
body:
Parts which are not directly or indirectly anchored can eventually corrode and disappear. The corrosion level, if any, is visible by hovering over the part with the Drag tool. Corrosion level is not saved, and has no effect besides the end result.

Non-valuable parts (under 100 credits except Trinkets/Relics) not connected to anything will rapidly corrode regardless of prevention. Underwater corrosion can only be prevented with a BallastTank.

Selecting the Wrench tool removes corrosion from all parts within 200 studs.

**PREVENTS CORROSION WITHIN 200 STUDS:**

-Players
-All types of running motors/engines
-Energy cells powering a load

**ACCELERATES CORROSION:**

-Events in progress
-Storms
-Deep ocean (without a BallastTank)

rapidly corrode regardless of prevention. Underwater corrosion can only be prevented with

cooler.title: Cooler
body:
Coolers cool down nearby players when powered.

If attached to an empty Container, active Coolers will slowly condense ambient air into LiquidNitrogen at a rate based on their size. This will not work in space or at high altitudes.
cooler.rawBody:
Coolers cool down nearby players when powered.

If attached to an empty Container, active Coolers will slowly condense ambient air into
LiquidNitrogen at a rate based on their size. This will not work in space or at high altitudes.

turbofan.title: Turbofan
body:
Turbofans provide thrust using a supply of Diesel or Gas. Thrust and fuel usage are increased by size, and the front of the Turbofan must not be blocked by parts during operation.

Nitroglycerin fed into a Turbofan, along with the normal fuel, greatly increases power output but causes damage with prolonged use.

Turbofans that take damage can be repaired using the Wrench tool.
turbofan.rawBody:
Turbofans provide thrust using a supply of Diesel or Gas. Thrust and fuel usage are increased
by size, and the front of the Turbofan must not be blocked by parts during operation.

Nitroglycerin fed into a Turbofan, along with the normal fuel, greatly increases power output
but causes damage with prolonged use.

Turbofans that take damage can be repaired using the Wrench tool.

footerData.name: Recipe
footerData.desc: Aluminium, Iron, Magnesium, Neodymium, Oil, Titanium

turboshaft.title: Turboshaft
body:
Turboshafts are identical to Turbofans except that they spin a hinge and can be linked with rods (using the Hammer's Link tool) unlike the Turbofan, but produce no thrust. They also do not require the intake to be uncovered, and are slightly quieter.

Nitroglycerin fed into a Turboshaft, along with the normal fuel, greatly increases power output but causes damage with prolonged use.

Turboshafts that take damage can be repaired using the Wrench tool.

Linking with a RodConstraint to a DriveBox creates a driveshaft that can turn the DriveBox's hinge.
turboshaft.rawBody:
Turboshafts are identical to Turbofans except that they spin a hinge and can be linked with
rods (using the Hammer's Link tool) unlike the Turbofan, but produce no thrust. They also do 
not require the intake to be uncovered, and are slightly quieter.

Nitroglycerin fed into a Turboshaft, along with the normal fuel, greatly increases power output
but causes damage with prolonged use.

Turboshafts that take damage can be repaired using the Wrench tool.

Linking with a RodConstraint to a DriveBox creates a driveshaft that can turn the 
DriveBox's hinge.

spotlight.title: SpotLight
body: SpotLights emit directional light when powered. Resize the SpotLight longer to increase the range and power usage, and resize it wider to increase the arc.
spotlight.rawBody:
SpotLights emit directional light when powered. Resize the SpotLight longer to increase the 
range and power usage, and resize it wider to increase the arc.

alkalinecell.title: AlkalineCell
body:
AlkalineCells are compact, non-rechargable energy cells which start with 500 energy when created.  All power circuits require use of an AlkalineCell or some other type of energy cell.

Unlike PowerCells and LithiumCells, AlkalineCells do not self-discharge under normal conditions and have a much higher tolerance of cold atmospheres. They have little resale value.

AlkalineCells must be fully charged to be used as a model loading ingredient.
alkalinecell.rawBody:
AlkalineCells are compact, non-rechargable energy cells which start with 500 energy when
created.  All power circuits require use of an AlkalineCell or some other type of energy cell.

Unlike PowerCells and LithiumCells, AlkalineCells do not self-discharge under normal conditions
and have a much higher tolerance of cold atmospheres. They have little resale value.

AlkalineCells must be fully charged to be used as a model loading ingredient.

programming.title: Programming
body:
Due to ROBLOX Age Segregation, letters from player input are now hidden.

Yewscript is a programming language unique to Scarlet Skies, used by in-game Computers.

The Keyboard's GUI has an upper and lower window for entering YewScript programs depending on the user's preference. In the upper window, instructions are seperated by new lines, and by slashes in the lower window. No spaces are used in the programming syntax (besides any spaces contained in strings).

Example for lower window: A=0/printA/A+1/goto2

Example for upper window:

A=0
printA
A+1
goto2

**=====SYNTAX=====**

Note that programs will only run if containing more than one instruction.

Each statement begins with its case-sensitive word, followed by arguments seperated from each other by apostrophes ('), but not seperated from the word.

Examples: printHello/wait3, signalHello'2/wait3

The only exception to this order is when setting or performing arithmetic on a variable, where the variable is first, followed by an operator.

Examples: A=Hello/printA/wait3, C=0/C+10/printC/wait3

"if" statements are also formed a bit differently, with no seperation between the arguments besides for the operator used. When the statement is false, all code between the "if" statement and the next "end" will be skipped. "else" may also be used in between these. Undefined variables are referred to as "nil".

Example: ifC>0/printLarger/else/printSmaller/end/wait3

Variables are referenced using capital letters from A to Z, giving a total of twenty-six RAM slots. Lists and dictionaries can be indexed in variables (except in instructions which begin with a variable) using the "\`" character followed by a number or key.

Examples: H=100/H\\2/printH/wait3, B=a;b;c/printB\`2/wait3

Lists are simply strings/numbers seperated by semicolons ";". Variable Z is special in that it is overwritten while looping through a "for" list, which is set to each item in the list as it loops. You may add to or remove from a list using "insert" and "remove".

Example: A=One;Two;Three/forA/printZ/wait1/endloop

Dictionaries are pairs of keys and data seperated by colons ":", with an additional colon at the
beginning, end, and between each pair. Use the "dict" instruction to remove (by setting to nil) or add entry pairs, which can then be indexed in the same way lists are indexed (A=B\`1). "for" and "A=Size" also operate on dictionaries similarly to lists.

Example: A=:User1::123:User2::456:/B=A\`User2/printB/leapto0

The "goto" and "leapto" instructions are used to jump to a specific line in the program, and can create loops if jumping to a previous section.

Examples: B=2/B\*2/printB/goto2, printPermanent Message!/leapto0

Comments (notes/markers that do nothing) are created by placing a "-" at the beginning of a line, as in wait1/-Marker/goto1.

**=====QUICK INSTRUCTION LIST=====**

reset: Resets all loops, settings, and clears all variables.
goto[line]: Jumps to [line] in the program.
lock[id]: Locks Computer until [id] entered on Channel 10. Use 0 to unlock.
box[id]'posX'posY'sizeX'sizeY'text'backcolor'color: Creates a text box.
imgbox[id]'posX'posY'sizeX'sizeY'imageid'backcolor'color: Creates an image.
change[id]'posX'posY'sizeX'sizeY'text or image'backcolor'color: Changes any GUI.
Negative colors on the above three will instead set transparency (-1 to 0).
delete[id]: Deletes any GUI.
errmode[num 0-1]: Ignores runtime errors if set to 0.
speed[num 1-6]: Sets processor speed. +2 limit for each cluster node. Default maximum.
beep[pitch 0-100]'[length]: Emits a sound. Length is optional.
for[data]: Loops over each dictionary or list item in [data], setting variable Z each time.
endloop: Marks the end of a "for" or "loop" section.
insert[variable]'[data]'[pos]: Inserts [data] into a list. [pos] is optional and replaces entries.
remove[variable]'[pos]: Removes item at [pos] from a list. Use -1 for first and 0 for last.
[variable][operator][data]: Sets/performs an operation on a variable.
beacon[id]'[data]: Broadcasts [data] across the network, expiring after 10 seconds.
loop[num]: Loops the following code section [num] times.
if[data1][comparator][data2]: Ignores the following section if the statement is false.
print[data]: Displays [data] on the monitor.
signal[data]'[channel 0-9]: Sends [data] signal through Mode [channel] Polysilicon.
sign[data]: Displays [data] on a Sign.
else: Used between an "if" and "end" to inverse the "if" statement.
wait[num]: Pauses the program for [num] seconds.
end: Marks the end of an "if" section.
leapto[lines]: Jumps forward or backward [lines] in the program, can be negative.
cube[id]'posX'posY'posZ'sizeX'sizeY'sizeZ'texture'color'rotX'rotY'rotZ: Creates a 3D object.
open3d: Starts the 3D renderer.
close3d: Stops the 3D renderer and deletes all 3D objects.
cam[posX]'posY'posZ'lookposX'lookposY'lookposZ: Moves the camera to "pos", looking at "lookpos".
camangle[rotX]'rotY'rotZ'distance'posX'posY'posZ: Rotates the camera, looking at "pos".
mod[id]'posX'posY'posZ'sizeX'sizeY'sizeZ'texture'color'rotX'rotY'rotZ: Changes a 3D object.
send[address]'[data]'[channel 0-12]: Transmits [data] to Computer at [address] through [channel].
sweep[variable]'[data]: Removes all instances of [data] from [list].
closebeacon[id]: Manually deletes data beacons of [id] from this Computer.
destroy[id]: Deletes a 3D object.
boot: Runs a saved program on the disk immediately when the Computer is powered.
encrypt: Prevents program from being read when saved on the disk.
credit[address]'[amount]: Sends [amount] credits to [address] if both have a Bank.
translate[id]'X'Y'Z'rotX'rotY'rotZ: Moves a cube relative to its current direction.
face[id]'posX'posY'posZ: Rotates a cube to face a position.
writefile[data]: Overwrites the Computer's internal memory to [data].
writechip[data]: Overwrites a connected MemoryChip to [data].
intercept[address]: Channel 10 network data going to [address] is redirected here for 6 seconds.
dial[address]: Stops current program and attempts to dial [address] server.
cursor[id]: Sets a box or imgbox to follow mouse position on the Keyboard's touchpad.
music[data]: Plays music. See below for details on music format.
replay: Loops the current or next music track to be played.
stopmusic: Stops the current music track.
affix[variable]'[data]: Affixes a string to another string.
dict[variable]'[data]'[key]: Creates or edits a dictionary pair. Use "nil" as [data] to remove.
sync[id]'[address]: Replicates a GUI from Computer at [address]. Can create/modify/delete.
sync3d[id]'[address]: Replicates a 3D object from Computer at [address]. Can create/modify/delete.

**=====MUSIC FORMAT=====**

Each note consists of a 2-digit pitch (00-99) and a 2-digit length (00-99). Length is measured in 1/40th of a second + 1/40. Create a pause by using a semicolon (;) followed by a 2-digit length.

Example: 0520;101020;101520

This would be read as 05 20 (note) ;10 (pause) 10 20 (note) ;10 (pause) 15 20 (note).

**=====ADVANCED: VARIABLE OPERATIONS=====**

[variable][operator][data]: Sets or performs an operation on a variable.

**OPERATORS**

Vectors (X;Y;Z) can be multiplied or divided by a regular number. They can also be added, subtracted, multiplied, or divided by another vector.

=: Sets [variable] to [data].
+: Adds [variable] to [data].
-: Subtracts [data] from [variable].
\* or \`: Multiplies [data] by [variable].
\\ (backwards slash): Divides [variable] by [data].
^: Multiplies [variable] by itself [data] number of times.
%: Remainder of [variable] divided by [data].
@: Rounds [variable] to whole number depending on [data]. -1 = lower, 1 = upper, 0 = closest.
>: Sets [variable] to [data] if [data] is less.
<: Sets [variable] to [data] if [data] is greater.

**KEYWORDS**

When setting a variable with "=", case-sensitive keywords can be used, as in C=Buffer'0.

Buffer'[channel 0-13]: Sets [slot] to the last data received from [ch] channel.
Rand'[min or max]'[max]: Random number. [min] and [max] are optional.
Time: Time elapsed in seconds since the program started.
Self: The source code of the running program.
CursorX: X position of the mouse on the Keyboard's touchpad.
CursorY: Y position of the mouse on the Keyboard's touchpad.
Port: Network address of the computer.
Scan'[id]: List of data being beaconed under [id]. Does not include beacons from the same Computer.
Prop2D'[id]'[argument number]: [argument] property of GUI [id]. (aka, Argument 3 would get posY)
Prop3D'[id]'[argument number]: [argument] property of cube [id]. (aka, Argument 3 would get posY)
Touch2D'[id]: List of GUIs touching GUI [id].
Touch3D'[id]: List of cubes touching cube [id].
Magnitude[X]'[Y]'[Z] or Magnitude[vector]: Distance of the vector.
Unit[X]'[Y]'[Z] or Unit[vector]: Unit of the vector.
Players: List of all players currently in the server.
User: Nearest nearby player to the Computer, if any.
Year: Game year.
Clock: In-game time of day, in minutes.
Length'[data]: String length of [data].
Size'[data]: Number of items in list or dictionary [data].
File: Program or data stored on the computer.
Chip: Program or data stored on the connected MemoryChip.
Realtime: Real-world time elapsed in seconds since January 1st, 1970.
Find'[list]'[data]: List position of the first occurrence of [data] in [list].
Examine'[address]: String length of program running on [address]. 0 if online but no program.
Funds: Credit amount in attached Bank.
Color'[R]'[G]'[B]: Converts RGB to BrickColor code. Accepts either 0-1 or 0-255.
IdUser'[player name]: Looks up a player's UserId number from their name.
NameUser'[userid]: Looks up a player's name from their UserId number.
Sub'[data]'[start]'[finish]: Substring of [data] from [start] until the optional [finish].
Swap'[data]: Converts a string to a list of numbers or vice versa.
Abs, Acos, Asin, Atan, Cos, Cosh, Deg, Rad, Sin, Sinh, Tan, Tanh, Btan: C Math.
All C Math functions use one number argument, except for Btan (atan2) which uses two.

**=====ADVANCED: IF=====**

if[data1][operator][data2]

**OPERATORS**

<: Less than
>: Greater than
{: Less than or equal to
}: Greater than or equal to
=: Equal to
!: Not equal to
[: String/list/dictionary contains (eg. "Helloworld" does contain "Hello")
]: String/list/dictionary does not contain (eg. "Helloworld" does not contain "Ree")

**KEYWORDS**

When using "=" or "!" as an operator, the type of data can be checked, as in ifA=String.

List: Data is a list.
String: Data contains letters or other non-number characters.
Number: Data is a number.
Dictionary: Data is a dictionary.

other by apostrophes ('), but not seperated from the word.

<font color="rgb(0,255,255)">Examples: printHello/wait3, signalHello'2/wait3</font>

The only exception to this order is when setting or performing arithmetic on a variable, where 
the variable is first, followed by an operator.

<font color="rgb(0,255,255)">Examples: A=Hello/printA/wait3, C=0/C+10/printC/wait3</font>

"if" statements are also formed a bit differently, with no seperation between the arguments besides
for the operator used. When the statement is false, all code between the "if" statement and the next
"end" will be skipped. "else" may also be used in between these. Undefined variables are referred to 
as "nil".

<font color="rgb(0,255,255)">Example: ifC>0/printLarger/else/printSmaller/end/wait3</font>

Variables are referenced using capital letters from A to Z, giving a total of twenty-six RAM 
slots. Lists and dictionaries can be indexed in variables (except in instructions which begin with
a variable) using the "`" character followed by a number or key.

<font color="rgb(0,255,255)">Examples: H=100/H\2/printH/wait3, B=a;b;c/printB`2/wait3</font>

Lists are simply strings/numbers seperated by semicolons ";". Variable Z is special in that 
it is overwritten while looping through a "for" list, which is set to each item in the list 
as it loops. You may add to or remove from a list using "insert" and "remove".

<font color="rgb(0,255,255)">Example: A=One;Two;Three/forA/printZ/wait1/endloop</font>

Dictionaries are pairs of keys and data seperated by colons ":", with an additional colon at the
beginning, end, and between each pair. Use the "dict" instruction to remove (by setting to nil) 
or add entry pairs, which can then be indexed in the same way lists are indexed (A=B`1). "for" 
and "A=Size" also operate on dictionaries similarly to lists.

<font color="rgb(0,255,255)">Example: A=:User1::123:User2::456:/B=A`User2/printB/leapto0</font>

The "goto" and "leapto" instructions are used to jump to a specific line in the program, and 
can create loops if jumping to a previous section.

<font color="rgb(0,255,255)">Examples: B=2/B*2/printB/goto2, printPermanent Message!/leapto0</font>

Comments (notes/markers that do nothing) are created by placing a "-" at the beginning of a
line, as in wait1/-Marker/goto1.

<font color="rgb(0,255,0)">=====QUICK INSTRUCTION LIST=====</font>

reset: Resets all loops, settings, and clears all variables.
goto[line]: Jumps to [line] in the program.
lock[id]: Locks Computer until [id] entered on Channel 10. Use 0 to unlock.
box[id]'posX'posY'sizeX'sizeY'text'backcolor'color: Creates a text box.
imgbox[id]'posX'posY'sizeX'sizeY'imageid'backcolor'color: Creates an image.
change[id]'posX'posY'sizeX'sizeY'text or image'backcolor'color: Changes any GUI.
Negative colors on the above three will instead set transparency (-1 to 0).
delete[id]: Deletes any GUI.
errmode[num 0-1]: Ignores runtime errors if set to 0.
speed[num 1-6]: Sets processor speed. +2 limit for each cluster node. Default maximum.
beep[pitch 0-100]'[length]: Emits a sound. Length is optional.
for[data]: Loops over each dictionary or list item in [data], setting variable Z each time.
endloop: Marks the end of a "for" or "loop" section.
insert[variable]'[data]'[pos]: Inserts [data] into a list. [pos] is optional and replaces entries.
remove[variable]'[pos]: Removes item at [pos] from a list. Use -1 for first and 0 for last.
[variable][operator][data]: Sets/performs an operation on a variable.
beacon[id]'[data]: Broadcasts [data] across the network, expiring after 10 seconds.
loop[num]: Loops the following code section [num] times.
if[data1][comparator][data2]: Ignores the following section if the statement is false.
print[data]: Displays [data] on the monitor.
signal[data]'[channel 0-9]: Sends [data] signal through Mode [channel] Polysilicon.
sign[data]: Displays [data] on a Sign.
else: Used between an "if" and "end" to inverse the "if" statement.
wait[num]: Pauses the program for [num] seconds.
end: Marks the end of an "if" section.
leapto[lines]: Jumps forward or backward [lines] in the program, can be negative.
cube[id]'posX'posY'posZ'sizeX'sizeY'sizeZ'texture'color'rotX'rotY'rotZ: Creates a 3D object.
open3d: Starts the 3D renderer.
close3d: Stops the 3D renderer and deletes all 3D objects.
cam[posX]'posY'posZ'lookposX'lookposY'lookposZ: Moves the camera to "pos", looking at "lookpos".
camangle[rotX]'rotY'rotZ'distance'posX'posY'posZ: Rotates the camera, looking at "pos".
mod[id]'posX'posY'posZ'sizeX'sizeY'sizeZ'texture'color'rotX'rotY'rotZ: Changes a 3D object.
send[address]'[data]'[channel 0-12]: Transmits [data] to Computer at [address] through [channel].
sweep[variable]'[data]: Removes all instances of [data] from [list].
closebeacon[id]: Manually deletes data beacons of [id] from this Computer.
destroy[id]: Deletes a 3D object.
boot: Runs a saved program on the disk immediately when the Computer is powered.
encrypt: Prevents program from being read when saved on the disk.
credit[address]'[amount]: Sends [amount] credits to [address] if both have a Bank.
translate[id]'X'Y'Z'rotX'rotY'rotZ: Moves a cube relative to its current direction.
face[id]'posX'posY'posZ: Rotates a cube to face a position.
writefile[data]: Overwrites the Computer's internal memory to [data].
writechip[data]: Overwrites a connected MemoryChip to [data].
intercept[address]: Channel 10 network data going to [address] is redirected here for 6 seconds.
dial[address]: Stops current program and attempts to dial [address] server.
cursor[id]: Sets a box or imgbox to follow mouse position on the Keyboard's touchpad.
music[data]: Plays music. See below for details on music format.
replay: Loops the current or next music track to be played.
stopmusic: Stops the current music track.
affix[variable]'[data]: Affixes a string to another string.
dict[variable]'[data]'[key]: Creates or edits a dictionary pair. Use "nil" as [data] to remove.
sync[id]'[address]: Replicates a GUI from Computer at [address]. Can create/modify/delete.
sync3d[id]'[address]: Replicates a 3D object from Computer at [address]. Can create/modify/delete.

<font color="rgb(0,255,0)">=====MUSIC FORMAT=====</font>

Each note consists of a 2-digit pitch (00-99) and a 2-digit length (00-99). Length is measured in
1/40th of a second + 1/40. Create a pause by using a semicolon (;) followed by a 2-digit length.

Example: 0520;101020;101520

This would be read as 05 20 (note) ;10 (pause) 10 20 (note) ;10 (pause) 15 20 (note).

<font color="rgb(0,255,0)">=====ADVANCED: VARIABLE OPERATIONS=====</font>

[variable][operator][data]: Sets or performs an operation on a variable.

OPERATORS

Vectors (X;Y;Z) can be multiplied or divided by a regular number. They can also be added,
subtracted, multiplied, or divided by another vector.

=: Sets [variable] to [data].
+: Adds [variable] to [data].
-: Subtracts [data] from [variable].
* or `: Multiplies [data] by [variable].
\ (backwards slash): Divides [variable] by [data].
^: Multiplies [variable] by itself [data] number of times.
%: Remainder of [variable] divided by [data].
@: Rounds [variable] to whole number depending on [data]. -1 = lower, 1 = upper, 0 = closest.
>: Sets [variable] to [data] if [data] is less.
<: Sets [variable] to [data] if [data] is greater.

KEYWORDS

When setting a variable with "=", case-sensitive keywords can be used, as in C=Buffer'0.

Buffer'[channel 0-13]: Sets [slot] to the last data received from [ch] channel.
Rand'[min or max]'[max]: Random number. [min] and [max] are optional.
Time: Time elapsed in seconds since the program started.
Self: The source code of the running program.
CursorX: X position of the mouse on the Keyboard's touchpad.
CursorY: Y position of the mouse on the Keyboard's touchpad.
Port: Network address of the computer.
Scan'[id]: List of data being beaconed under [id]. Does not include beacons from the same Computer.
Prop2D'[id]'[argument number]: [argument] property of GUI [id]. (aka, Argument 3 would get posY)
Prop3D'[id]'[argument number]: [argument] property of cube [id]. (aka, Argument 3 would get posY)
Touch2D'[id]: List of GUIs touching GUI [id].
Touch3D'[id]: List of cubes touching cube [id].
Magnitude[X]'[Y]'[Z] or Magnitude[vector]: Distance of the vector.
Unit[X]'[Y]'[Z] or Unit[vector]: Unit of the vector.
Players: List of all players currently in the server.
User: Nearest nearby player to the Computer, if any.
Year: Game year.
Clock: In-game time of day, in minutes.
Length'[data]: String length of [data].
Size'[data]: Number of items in list or dictionary [data].
File: Program or data stored on the computer.
Chip: Program or data stored on the connected MemoryChip.
Realtime: Real-world time elapsed in seconds since January 1st, 1970.
Find'[list]'[data]: List position of the first occurrence of [data] in [list].
Examine'[address]: String length of program running on [address]. 0 if online but no program.
Funds: Credit amount in attached Bank.
Color'[R]'[G]'[B]: Converts RGB to BrickColor code. Accepts either 0-1 or 0-255.
IdUser'[player name]: Looks up a player's UserId number from their name.
NameUser'[userid]: Looks up a player's name from their UserId number.
Sub'[data]'[start]'[finish]: Substring of [data] from [start] until the optional [finish].
Swap'[data]: Converts a string to a list of numbers or vice versa.
Abs, Acos, Asin, Atan, Cos, Cosh, Deg, Rad, Sin, Sinh, Tan, Tanh, Btan: C Math.
All C Math functions use one number argument, except for Btan (atan2) which uses two.

<font color="rgb(0,255,0)">=====ADVANCED: IF=====</font>

if[data1][operator][data2]

OPERATORS

<: Less than
>: Greater than
{: Less than or equal to
}: Greater than or equal to
=: Equal to
!: Not equal to
[: String/list/dictionary contains (eg. "Helloworld" does contain "Hello")
]: String/list/dictionary does not contain (eg. "Helloworld" does not contain "Ree")

KEYWORDS

When using "=" or "!" as an operator, the type of data can be checked, as in ifA=String.

List: Data is a list.
String: Data contains letters or other non-number characters.
Number: Data is a number.
Dictionary: Data is a dictionary.

commlink.title: Commlink
body: A Commlink converts player chats to signals. The first signal entry is the message, while the second entry is the player's name. Larger Commlinks will recieve chats from much further away, and vice versa.
commlink.rawBody:
A Commlink converts player chats to signals. The first signal entry is the message,
while the second entry is the player's name. Larger Commlinks will recieve chats from
much further away, and vice versa.

geigercounter.title: GeigerCounter
body: GeigerCounters measure the level of nearby ionizing radiation. Rapid clicks indicate dangerous levels, and the light will turn increasingly red.
geigercounter.rawBody:
GeigerCounters measure the level of nearby ionizing radiation. Rapid clicks indicate 
dangerous levels, and the light will turn increasingly red.

radiationsuit.title: RadiationSuit
body: A RadiationSuit will provide resistance against ionizing radiation. It can greatly reduce of most types of radiation, but is ineffective with very high amounts.
radiationsuit.rawBody:
A RadiationSuit will provide resistance against ionizing radiation. It can greatly 
reduce of most types of radiation, but is ineffective with very high amounts.

bow.title: Bow
body:
Bows fire arrows which stick to objects (except for Aluminium ammo).

Bow Ammunitions (load an ammo by using the Ammo button in Produce GUI):

-Default: Normal arrow.

-Copper: Poison arrow with less initial damage, but deals damage over time.

-Oil: Flaming arrow with a chance to set a target on fire after a while.

-Aluminium: Sonic wave which destroys Anchors, Cannon shots, and in-flight Rockets/Missiles.

Bows are the only way to destroy Monsters.
bow.rawBody:
Bows fire arrows which stick to objects (except for Aluminium ammo).

Bow Ammunitions (load an ammo by using the Ammo button in Produce GUI):

-Default: Normal arrow.

-Copper: Poison arrow with less initial damage, but deals damage over time.

-Oil: Flaming arrow with a chance to set a target on fire after a while.

-Aluminium: Sonic wave which destroys Anchors, Cannon shots, and in-flight Rockets/Missiles.

Bows are the only way to destroy Monsters.

faucet.title: Faucet
body:
Faucets release substances from Containers connected directly or through Pipe with a range based on the local pressure, which depends on how far the Container is above the Faucet unless either are in space. When aimed at another Container, the substance will be transferred if applicable. Connecting a Faucet to both CompressedAir and another substance increases the pressure dramatically. Active Faucets turn yellow if not enough pressure is available. Gaseous substances generate their own pressure and provide thrust on the Faucet, while all substances will push back on parts they are pointed toward (except Vacuum, which pulls).

The width of a Faucet determines how fast the substance will be released. Click the Faucet or use Polysilicon to toggle it on or off.

Releasing different substances has different effects:

-Ammo: Pushes parts more strongly than gases or liquids.
-Coal: Pushes parts more strongly than gases or liquids.
-Water: Puts out fires.
-HeatedWater: Puts out fires.
-Nitroglycerin: Causes explosions when under high pressure. Inserted as ammo in Guns/Cannons.
-LiquidNitrogen: Freezes parts into Debris and players into Ice.
-Diesel: Increases flammability, and temporarily allows fire to burn across non-flammables.
-Acid: Dissolves parts.
-ProtaliumOxide: Reacts with Amethyst to create ExoticMatter.
-Gas: Spreads fire, produces a small amount of thrust.
-Hydrogen: Spreads fire, produces a small amount of thrust.
-Toxin: Poisons players/bots and lingers near the ground.
-Steam: Produces a small amount of thrust.
-CompressedAir: Produces a larger amount of thrust.
-Vacuum: Sucks items toward the Faucet and produces a small amount of backward thrust.
-Mercury: Releases individual droplets which capture and re-emit signals on contact.
-Polish: Removes 25% selling penalty from parts and causes players to drop more Credits on death.
-Aramid: Increases strength of parts. The effect is reduced depending on the initial strength.

combolock.title: ComboLock
body:
The ComboLock will signal parts connected to it only if the correct password is dialed. If directly connected to a DoorTemplate, the DoorTemplate will be un-openable except by the ComboLock. They are normally the strength of Titanium, but gain strength while connected to Eridanium or stronger.

Adjust the password with the Hammer's Config Tool.
combolock.rawBody:
The ComboLock will signal parts connected to it only if the correct password is dialed.
If directly connected to a DoorTemplate, the DoorTemplate will be un-openable except by 
the ComboLock. They are normally the strength of Titanium, but gain strength while 
connected to Eridanium or stronger.

Adjust the password with the Hammer's Config Tool.

carbonfiber.title: CarbonFiber
body: CarbonFiber is a relatively strong and lightweight material. Though only moderately malleable and damaged by weather, it can be useful for situations requiring a high strength-to-weight ratio. CarbonFiber is also immune to LiquidNitrogen.
carbonfiber.rawBody:
CarbonFiber is a relatively strong and lightweight material. Though only moderately malleable 
and damaged by weather, it can be useful for situations requiring a high strength-to-weight 
ratio. CarbonFiber is also immune to LiquidNitrogen.

lab.title: Lab
body:
Labs combine two inserted parts to create new ones. 

Combining the properties of parts besides Cannons and Uranium can only be done if the Lab is located in space. This will create a Hybrid after the process is completed and requires no energy. The Hybrid's properties will depend on the order in which the two parts were inserted. Hybrids are not saved when the world is reloaded. 

Insert two Cannons into a Lab for a small chance to produce Experimental Weapons which have randomized abilities and do not require Ammo Containers. Experimental Weapon properties are not saved when the world is reloaded.

Insert two pieces of Uranium into a Lab to create EnrichedUranium. The Lab must be powered throughout the process, and it will not accept the second Uranium unless powered. Enrichment cannot take place underwater.

Lab products (Experimental Weapons, EnrichedUranium, and Hybrids) cannot be inserted into Labs.

is located in space. This will create a Hybrid after the process is completed and requires

footerData.name: Uses
footerData.desc: Experimental Weapons, Enriching Uranium, Part Hybrids

footerData.desc: Copper, Gold, Neodymium, Ruby, Silicon, Sulfur

instrument.title: Instrument
body:
Instruments measure specific data points which can be read. Adjust the Instrument mode with the Hammer's Config Tool. When signaled, they will output their reading through Mode 3 Polysilicon.

**LIST OF MODES**
1: Speed. Instrument's total velocity.
2: Meter. Can be connected to pipes or wires to display the substance and amount contained
within Containers or energy cells.
3: Position. Relative to Earth's center at sea level. Displayed as X;Y;Z.
4: GUI. Copies up to 10 surface GUIs of attached parts and displays them onscreen for players 
in attached seats. GUI buttons will function only on Controllers, Keypads, and ComboLocks. 5: Weight. Shows total weight of all directly or indirectly connected parts, unless connected
to terrain, in which case it will show the weight of all parts within 100 studs.
6: RotSpeed. Instrument's total rotational velocity.
7: Odometer. Number of studs traveled since set to this mode.
8: Usage. Similar to mode 2, but instead shows the approximate change per second. Note that
values shown will not be 100% accurate.
9: Age. Shows the minutes since the Instrument was created or last adjusted. This value will 
save across servers.
10: Part Count. Shows amount of all directly or indirectly connected parts, unless connected
to terrain, in which case it will count all parts within 100 studs.
11: Rotation. Instrument's 3D rotation as X;Y;Z.
12: SpeedVector. Instrument's 3D velocity as X;Y;Z.
13: RotVector. Instrument's 3D rotational velocity as X;Y;Z.
14: SpeedForward. Instrument's forward velocity.
15: Multi. Does not display on the Instrument, but combines the following into a single output:
Speed, PositionX,Y,Z, RotSpeed, RotationX,Y,Z, SpeedVectorX,Y,Z, RotVectorX,Y,Z, SpeedForward 16: Source. Can be connected to pipes or wires to display the location of the Container or 
energy cell. Displayed as X;Y;Z.
17: Hull. Shows flood percentage of a connected Hull or CrudeHull.
18: Temperature. Ambient air temperature (not including Heaters, Coolers, or other sources).

armor.title: Armor
body:
Armor is a jacket that can be worn to protect against damage.

It restricts movement like the SpaceSuit, but reduces 50% of most types of damage.
armor.rawBody:
Armor is a jacket that can be worn to protect against damage.

It restricts movement like the SpaceSuit, but reduces 50% of most types of damage.

brick.title: Brick
body: A material that is heavier but stronger than Stone, and more malleable.
brick.rawBody: A material that is heavier but stronger than Stone, and more malleable.

arcolantium.title: Arcolantium
body: Arcolantium is a heavy and incredibly strong material, being stronger than Eridanium but less malleable.
arcolantium.rawBody:
Arcolantium is a heavy and incredibly strong material, being stronger than Eridanium but
less malleable.

teleporter.title: Teleporter
body:
Teleporters are able to quickly transport players unlimited distances.

The Teleporter's ID is set with the Hammer's Config Tool; set two Teleporters to the same ID to use. A Teleporter can remain connected to another even if the other Teleporter's ID is changed. 

To use, step onto the Teleporter and wait about 10 seconds. Energy is drained from both the sending and recieving Teleporter; however, power to the recieving Teleporter is not required.

Signal the Teleporter with Polysilicon to enable or disable both incoming and outgoing teleports.
teleporter.rawBody:
Teleporters are able to quickly transport players unlimited distances.

The Teleporter's ID is set with the Hammer's Config Tool; set two Teleporters to the
same ID to use. A Teleporter can remain connected to another even if the other 
Teleporter's ID is changed. 

To use, step onto the Teleporter and wait about 10 seconds. Energy is drained from
both the sending and recieving Teleporter; however, power to the recieving Teleporter
is not required.

Signal the Teleporter with Polysilicon to enable or disable both incoming and outgoing
teleports.

footerData.desc: Diamond, Gold, Quartz, Ruby, Silicon, Zaktralia

basecenter.title: BaseCenter
body:
BaseCenters function as spawn points and as a defense against intruders.

Outside of team Events, a BaseCenter's settings can be modified by clicking on it. Only the player who locked the BaseCenter can do this. A list of player names, seperated by spaces, will be allowed at the BaseCenter if set to "Whitelist", and disallowed if set to "Blacklist". The Public/Private setting determines whether the BaseCenter can be used as a spawn location. If a Safe BaseCenter does not yet exist in the map, the BaseCenter can be designated as such by clicking "Safe" as long as the other settings are left default. This allows players to Secure anchored parts within 700 studs of the BaseCenter, making them indestructible. Most part weapons also will not function nearby.

BaseCenters disable for at least 60 seconds after being moved. While active, they will output a signal (name;distance) if a disallowed player is detected nearby, and, if a teamed Event is in progress, will also throw a spiky projectile at the player which only kills if the target is not in a seat or is in an aircraft which flew too low or landed nearby. Players flying with JetPacks or ParachutePacks will not be killed.

If recently damaged, dragging a BaseCenter is temporarily impossible. Outside of territory Events such as War, the BaseCenter will become will become invulnerable (except to Warheads) for 60 seconds each time its health is drained by 25%.

BaseCenters will despawn if placed underwater. During team events, they must also have a clear and open area around them - as well as being placed less than 27 studs above sea level - to prevent encroachment damage over time.

In teamed Events, BaseCenters will eventually spawn a new Factory if all previous Factories nearby were lost or destroyed. This backup Factory is marked as "Damaged", meaning it is worth very little to sell, though it will contain the materials of the previous Factories. BaseCenters will also unlock if their owner leaves the game during these Events.

setting determines whether the BaseCenter can be used as a spawn location. If a Safe BaseCenter does

or ParachutePacks will not be killed.

If recently damaged, dragging a BaseCenter is temporarily impossible. Outside of territory Events
such as War, the BaseCenter will become will become invulnerable (except to Warheads) for 60 seconds
each time its health is drained by 25%.

BaseCenters will despawn if placed underwater. During team events, they must also have a clear and 
open area around them - as well as being placed less than 27 studs above sea level - to prevent 
encroachment damage over time.

In teamed Events, BaseCenters will eventually spawn a new Factory if all previous Factories nearby
were lost or destroyed. This backup Factory is marked as "Damaged", meaning it is worth very little
to sell, though it will contain the materials of the previous Factories. BaseCenters will also unlock 
if their owner leaves the game during these Events.

jade.title: Jade
body: Jade is a valuable green gem used in several item recipes which cannot be produced by a Factory.
jade.rawBody:
Jade is a valuable green gem used in several item recipes which cannot be produced by
a Factory.

steamengine.title: SteamEngine
body:
SteamEngines convert Steam pressure into motion.

Connect a Container of Steam (directly or through Pipe/Valve/Controller) to operate the SteamEngine. The easiest way to create Steam is by heating a Container of Water using Fireboxes.

Parts attached to the hinge on the SteamEngine will spin at a speed that can be set with the Hammer's Config Tool, as well as the direction. Speed 1 is idle and does not transmit power to the hinge.

Linking with a RodConstraint to a DriveBox creates a driveshaft that can turn the DriveBox's hinge.
steamengine.rawBody:
SteamEngines convert Steam pressure into motion.

Connect a Container of Steam (directly or through Pipe/Valve/Controller) to operate
the SteamEngine. The easiest way to create Steam is by heating a Container of Water 
using Fireboxes.

Parts attached to the hinge on the SteamEngine will spin at a speed that can be
set with the Hammer's Config Tool, as well as the direction. Speed 1 is idle and 
does not transmit power to the hinge.

Linking with a RodConstraint to a DriveBox creates a driveshaft that can turn the 
DriveBox's hinge.

drivebox.title: DriveBox
body:
DriveBoxes are linked to Engines, Motors or other motor types through a RodConstraint (created by the Hammer's Link tool) to apply torque at a distance. Each additional DriveBox linked to the motor reduces the torque provided to all other outputs.

Use the Hammer's Config tool to reverse the DriveBox or to set the gear ratio, which increases the output speed at the cost of torque (or vice versa). Some items, such as Propellers and Rotors, do not function with a DriveBox and must instead be directly driven by the motor.

Signaling Polysilicon connected to a DriveBox will activate or deactivate it.
drivebox.rawBody:
DriveBoxes are linked to Engines, Motors or other motor types through a RodConstraint (created
by the Hammer's Link tool) to apply torque at a distance. Each additional DriveBox linked to the
motor reduces the torque provided to all other outputs.

Use the Hammer's Config tool to reverse the DriveBox or to set the gear ratio, which increases
the output speed at the cost of torque (or vice versa). Some items, such as Propellers and Rotors,
do not function with a DriveBox and must instead be directly driven by the motor.

Signaling Polysilicon connected to a DriveBox will activate or deactivate it.

energycannon.title: EnergyCannon
body:
EnergyCannons fire charged projectiles in a fashion similar to the Cannon. They are extremely customizable, with five different ammunition slots that contribute to the properties of the weapon, giving 42236 possible EnergyCannon types. Insert a part into the EnergyCannon for each slot. EnergyCannons must be powered to fire and will not work if the front is blocked. If the EnergyCannon is locked, its projectiles will not damage parts locked by the same player.

EnergyCannons only function on the Space server.

**POSSIBLE AMMO FOR EACH SLOT**
Items are in order of their ID number seen when hovered over with Drag tool. For example, EnergyCannon (1x0x0x0x0) would have Eridanium in the first slot.

Slot 1 (projectile type): none, Eridanium, BeamCannon, Neodymium, Abantium, Lirvanite

Slot 2 (strength/weakness vs. certain object types): none, Lirvanite, LightningRod, 
Abantium, Protalium, Eridanium, ExoticMatter

Slot 3 (boosts a weapon stat): none, Zaktralia, GammaDrive, LiquidNitrogen, GravDevice, 
Protalium, Uranium

Slots 4 and 5 (special abilities): none, Goo, Abantium, Jade, Lirvanite, Protalium, 
ProtaliumOxide, Eridanium, Sulfur, Nitroglycerin, Zaktralia, IonDrive

**PROJECTILE TYPE**
0. [none]: Ball lightning with a quick rate of fire.
1. [Eridanium]: Fast-moving plasma fireball.
2. [BeamCannon]: Invisible tracefire ray, not compatible with "Projectile" effects.
3. [Neodymium]: Explosive star bomb.
4. [Abantium]: Energy pulse which has increased damage, but dissipates the further it travels.
5. [Lirvanite]: Vortex wave with a huge area of effect.
**BASIC DAMAGE ABILITY**
0. [none]: Best vs. players or bots.
1. [Lirvanite]: Best vs. strong parts (Eridanium, Lirvanite, etc).
2. [LightningRod]: Best vs. weak parts (Wood, Aluminium, etc).
3. [Abantium]: Best vs. any part, but less overall.
4. [Protalium]: Best vs. energy shields.
5. [Eridanium]: Best vs. medium-strength parts (Iron, Titanium, etc).
6. [Y]: Chaos projectile which splits on impact.
STAT BOOST
0. [none]: No effect.
1. [Zaktralia]: Damage increase.
2. [GammaDrive]: Fire rate increase.
3. [Gold]: Range increase.
4. [GravDevice]: Projectile speed increase.
5. [Protalium]: Power usage is greatly reduced.
6. [Uranium]: All stats increased a mediocre amount.
EFFECTS (SLOTS 4 AND 5)
0. [none]: No effect.
1. [Goo]: Splashes permanent residue of the projectile's color.
2. [Abantium]: Energy shockwave which conducts through metal and fries electronics.
3. [Jade]: Projectile can phase through the first layer of armor.
4. [Lirvanite]: Projectile absorbs other projectiles and massively gains strength.
5. [Protalium]: Shattering shockwave that can break multiple parts at once.
6. [PhotonShard]: Explodes on impact (or stronger Bombs). Slow firing and short range.
7. [Eridanium]: Disrupts cloaks, and deals more damage to energy shields.
8. [Sulfur]: Corrosive acid splash that eats away at corrodable materials.
9. [Amethyst]: Inferno splash which sets parts on fire.
10. [Zaktralia]: Projectile locks on and seeks what the weapon is pointing at.
11. [IonDrive]: Concussion force which repulses the target backwards.

treads.title: Treads
body:
Treads are a method of moving land vehicles. It is recommended that wedges are attached to the front and back (facing down) for better performance over rough terrain. The force of the Treads is determined by their surface area, and speed increases with height.

To use Treads, they must be linked by a RodConstraint (with the Hammer's Constraint tool) to an Engine, Motor or SteamEngine. They will operate at the speed of the engine they are connected to.

Treads are slower and noisier than wheels, but they are stronger and can climb over obstacles (with Wedges attached) with superior traction.

The Hammer's Config Tool can change the direction of the Treads.
treads.rawBody:
Treads are a method of moving land vehicles. It is recommended that wedges are attached
to the front and back (facing down) for better performance over rough terrain. The force
of the Treads is determined by their surface area, and speed increases with height.

To use Treads, they must be linked by a RodConstraint (with the Hammer's Constraint tool)
to an Engine, Motor or SteamEngine. They will operate at the speed of the engine they
are connected to.

Treads are slower and noisier than wheels, but they are stronger and can climb over obstacles
(with Wedges attached) with superior traction.

The Hammer's Config Tool can change the direction of the Treads.

levitator.title: Levitator
body:
The Levitator is a hovering part that can be used for amphibious vehicles.

Powering the Levitator will cause it to hover above the ground (make sure the decal is pointing upwards), with a height based on its size. It can hover over water or any terrain, and when used properly, can even ascend the steepest of slopes and straight over walls/mountains.
levitator.rawBody:
The Levitator is a hovering part that can be used for amphibious vehicles.

Powering the Levitator will cause it to hover above the ground (make sure the decal is 
pointing upwards), with a height based on its size. It can hover over water or any
terrain, and when used properly, can even ascend the steepest of slopes and straight
over walls/mountains.

aethergate.title: AetherGate
body:
AetherGates generate time portals able to send parts up to 25 in-game years into the future.

Connect the AetherGate to a TimeMachine and set the TimeMachine's year to the destination year, then power and signal the AetherGate to activate. Signal again to shut down.
aethergate.rawBody:
AetherGates generate time portals able to send parts up to 25 in-game years into the future.

Connect the AetherGate to a TimeMachine and set the TimeMachine's year to the destination
year, then power and signal the AetherGate to activate. Signal again to shut down.

templates.title: Templates
body:
**PARTS: TEMPLATES**

There are seven template parts that can be used to make other materials into different shapes and uses. Attach a template part to a material for a few seconds to make the template into that material, if compatible. Template parts save their material.

Parts:

-WedgeTemplate: Wedge shape.
-BallTemplate: Ball shape.
-WheelTemplate: Hinged wheel shape. Heavy (except Plastic). Low friction (except Rubber/Lirvanite).
-BladeTemplate: Rounded shape that can break parts when moving, depending on the strength of the
material used. Stronger blades harvest plants and mine surface ores, but can deplete the mine when used too often. Blades cannot damage parts locked by the same player, and they reduce the ability of trains to break through snow berms during Apocalypse GreatFreeze.
-DoorTemplate: Signal to open/close. Can be locked with a ComboLock.
-CornerTemplate: Corner wedge shape.
-PlateTemplate: Flat shape (0.2 studs thick). Strength is reduced by 33%.

**LIST OF TEMPLATE MATERIALS:**

Flubber, SeaAlloy, Lexan, Aluminium, Copper, Gold, Iron, Magnesium, Titanium, Eridanium, Abantium, Wood, Rubber, Wire, Pipe, SignalWire, Plastic, Glass, TintedGlass, Arcolantium, Ice, Quartz, Stone, Amethyst, Brick, Concrete, CarbonFiber, Ceramic, Y, Foam, Uranium, Gel, Jade, ZapWire, Lirvanite, Neodymium, BioWall, OrganicMatter, Silicon, Switch, SignalSwitch, TouchTrigger, Valve, Zaktralia, Button, PsiButton, Sandstone, Ghostalum, BurstWire, Funium, InsulatedWire

actuator.title: Actuator
body:
Actuators use energy to slide another part back and forth, converting energy to motion in a manner similar to Motors.

The part to be acted upon must be welded to the decal face of the Actuator with the same angle of rotation. The Actuator will flash red if the part is not rotated exactly the same way. Once activated, the part will align inside the center of the Actuator.

Power the Actuator and signal directly with number data to set a specific position in studs, or signal through Polysilicon to peform these operations:

-Mode 0 Polysilicon: Extends the full length of the part.
-Mode 1 Polysilicon: Retracts the full length of the part.
-Mode 2 Polysilicon: Returns part to the center position.

Use the Hammer's Config Tool to set the Actuator's speed.

Actuators use energy to slide another part back and forth, converting energy to motion in a manner
similar to Motors.

The part to be acted upon must be welded to the decal face of the Actuator with the same angle
of rotation. The Actuator will flash red if the part is not rotated exactly the same way. Once
activated, the part will align inside the center of the Actuator.

Power the Actuator and signal directly with number data to set a specific position in studs, or
signal through Polysilicon to peform these operations:

-Mode 0 Polysilicon: Extends the full length of the part.
-Mode 1 Polysilicon: Retracts the full length of the part.
-Mode 2 Polysilicon: Returns part to the center position.

Use the Hammer's Config Tool to set the Actuator's speed.

bot.title: Bot
body:
**OBJECT: BOT**

Bots are NPC humanoids which can be created or encountered throughout the game.

**CLASSES**

-Automaton: Appears when a BotSpawn is created by a player. Automatons follow orders from their
creator without question.

-Rogue: Rogues are technologically advanced, having left Earth centuries ago, and can be
seen in outer space. They are the guardians of Relics and are hostile to all players and other Bots.

**AUTOMATON ORDERS**

Each order must be given in chat, along with the Automaton's name in the sentence (or use "all" to speak to all Automatons under your control).
bot.rawBody:
OBJECT: BOT

Bots are NPC humanoids which can be created or encountered throughout the game.

CLASSES

-Automaton: Appears when a BotSpawn is created by a player. Automatons follow orders from their
creator without question.

-Rogue: Rogues are technologically advanced, having left Earth centuries ago, and can be
seen in outer space. They are the guardians of Relics and are hostile to all players and
other Bots.

AUTOMATON ORDERS

Each order must be given in chat, along with the Automaton's name in the sentence (or use
"all" to speak to all Automatons under your control).

footerData.name: -Roam
footerData.desc: Stop following the player, and wander away at will.

footerData.name: -Hate [name]
footerData.desc: Attack the named player/bot whenever in sight.

footerData.name: -Forgive [name]
footerData.desc: Do not attack the named player/bot in sight anymore.

footerData.name: -Sit
footerData.desc: Sit in the nearest regular seat, as a passenger.

footerData.name: -Get Out
footerData.desc: Get out of a vehicle or seat.

empbomb.title: EMPBomb
body:
An EMPBomb is a special explosive device that is harmless to parts (except for damaged/ corroded parts) and weak against players, but drains and disables any power source in its radius for two minutes. Unlike most explosions, this effect is not blocked by walls, though the effective radius is small.

EMPBomb explosions are also powerful against EnergyShields and can disrupt cloaks.
empbomb.rawBody:
An EMPBomb is a special explosive device that is harmless to parts (except for damaged/
corroded parts) and weak against players, but drains and disables any power source in
its radius for two minutes. Unlike most explosions, this effect is not blocked by walls,
though the effective radius is small.

EMPBomb explosions are also powerful against EnergyShields and can disrupt cloaks.

missile.title: Missile
body:
Missiles are single-use solid rocket motors which require no additional fuel. They cannot safely carry players or escape Earth's atmosphere by themselves (though they work in space).

Signal the Missile to light it. They are best signaled with red SignalWires to launch them, since red SignalWires despawn when activated. The length of time the Missile flies is determined by the length. After it burns out, it will eventually despawn.

In addition to providing propulsion, Missiles will also provide a limited amount of power to directly connected items while in flight (cannot transfer through Wires). This can be useful to power Seekers.
missile.rawBody:
Missiles are single-use solid rocket motors which require no additional fuel. They cannot
safely carry players or escape Earth's atmosphere by themselves (though they work in space).

Signal the Missile to light it. They are best signaled with red SignalWires to launch
them, since red SignalWires despawn when activated. The length of time the Missile flies 
is determined by the length. After it burns out, it will eventually despawn.

In addition to providing propulsion, Missiles will also provide a limited amount of power 
to directly connected items while in flight (cannot transfer through Wires). This can be 
useful to power Seekers.

ballasttank.title: BallastTank
body:
A BallastTank allows submarines to float at different water heights. A Controller will control the dive depth. BallastTanks slow down seacraft considerably, and may require more power to propel. Resize the BallastTank to control the buoyant force.

NOTE: BallastTanks also provide protection within a large radius against seawater corrosion;
however, when in seawater, they also greatly accelerate corrosion of most basic metals and structural parts on the same vehicle, requiring submarines to be armored with parts immune to this effect (such as SeaAlloy, Gold, or space materials).

BallastTanks which have already been placed in water will become extremely difficult to move if lifted out of the water.

In the War event, players must be near a BallastTank, CrudeHull, or Hull on the ocean surface to capture sea territories.
ballasttank.rawBody:
A BallastTank allows submarines to float at different water heights. A Controller will
control the dive depth. BallastTanks slow down seacraft considerably, and may require more
power to propel. Resize the BallastTank to control the buoyant force.

NOTE: BallastTanks also provide protection within a large radius against seawater corrosion;
however, when in seawater, they also greatly accelerate corrosion of most basic metals and
structural parts on the same vehicle, requiring submarines to be armored with parts immune
to this effect (such as SeaAlloy, Gold, or space materials).

BallastTanks which have already been placed in water will become extremely difficult to move 
if lifted out of the water.

In the War event, players must be near a BallastTank, CrudeHull, or Hull on the ocean surface
to capture sea territories.

lift.title: Lift
body:
A Lift is a motorized part that can climb walls.

To use, the back of the Lift must be directly adjacent to the part to be climbed (such as an elevator shaft wall). Simply power the Lift, and click the Lift's buttons to make it move up, down, or stop.

Polysilicon can be used to control Lifts: Mode 0 for up, Mode 1 for down, Mode 2 for stop.
lift.rawBody:
A Lift is a motorized part that can climb walls.

To use, the back of the Lift must be directly adjacent to the part to be climbed (such as 
an elevator shaft wall). Simply power the Lift, and click the Lift's buttons to make 
it move up, down, or stop.

Polysilicon can be used to control Lifts: Mode 0 for up, Mode 1 for down, Mode 2 for stop.

gun.title: Gun
body:
Guns are tracefire weapons which fire high-speed bullets or shells.

Resize the Gun longer to increase the range, and wider to increase damage. Use the Hammer's Config tool to modify the caliber of the bullet. Higher calibers have more damage and slightly higher range, but fire slower and are less efficient with ammo usage.

Gun range is reduced significantly when underwater, and their bullets are less effective when many are hitting the same target at once.

Like Cannons, Guns must be loaded with a material before use (only when the Gun is unlocked) which determines the properties of the projectile.

**PROJECTILE TYPES:**

-Titanium: Long range bullet.
-Copper: Rapid-firing bullet with less accuracy and shorter range.
-Uranium: Powerful, accurate bullet with very long range but slow fire rate.
-Explosives: Flak shell intended for use against aircraft, bursting into fragments
when fired toward the sky. Flak Guns must be at least 4 studs wide and 8 studs long. -Nitroglycerin: Powerful exploding shell. Very heavy. Shell Guns must be at least 2 studs wide
and 8 studs long to function.
-Y: Extremely powerful antimatter bullet which instantly destroys most parts.
	
Guns are fired by signaling/clicking them, but need to be connected with an Ammo container.

spacejet.title: SpaceJet
body:
The SpaceJet produces a small amount of thrust in the direction the mouse is pointed. Though the thrust is too small to be of much use on Earth, the SpaceJet allows controlled movement through space.

SpaceJets have a limited amount of fuel.
spacejet.rawBody:
The SpaceJet produces a small amount of thrust in the direction the mouse is pointed.
Though the thrust is too small to be of much use on Earth, the SpaceJet allows 
controlled movement through space.

SpaceJets have a limited amount of fuel.

gammadrive.title: GammaDrive
body:
A GammaDrive is a type of spaceship engine, converting energy to force.

The GammaDrive is the fastest of all the spaceship engine types, and is fairly compact. However, it is much more inefficient, weaker, and has less weight capacity then the IonRocket. It also creates a bright particle stream, making it less stealthy.
gammadrive.rawBody:
A GammaDrive is a type of spaceship engine, converting energy to force.

The GammaDrive is the fastest of all the spaceship engine types, and is fairly compact.
However, it is much more inefficient, weaker, and has less weight capacity then the
IonRocket. It also creates a bright particle stream, making it less stealthy.

lirvanite.title: Lirvanite
body: Lirvanite is a shiny crystalloid found on asteroids. It is unique, valuable, relatively light, and as strong as Diamond. Lirvanite is the only space material that doesn't require refining.
lirvanite.rawBody:
Lirvanite is a shiny crystalloid found on asteroids. It is unique, valuable, relatively light, 
and as strong as Diamond. Lirvanite is the only space material that doesn't require refining.

sulfur.title: Sulfur
body:
Sulfur is a substance neccesary for producing many items.

It emits a blue flame when burned.
sulfur.rawBody:
Sulfur is a substance neccesary for producing many items.

It emits a blue flame when burned.

bank.title: Bank
body:
Banks are storage boxes for credits.

Left-clicking on a Bank will deposit 100 credits for the player who locked it, or 25 Credits for any other player. Right-clicking withdraws 100 credits for the player who locked it.

Signal a Bank through Mode 0 Polysilicon to eject a Credit bag of the amount signaled. Note that the Polysilicon must be locked by the same player who locked the Bank. Credit bags can also be inserted into the Bank on contact, albeit with a 4 credit penalty.

Signal a Bank directly to output the credit amount through Mode 3 Polysilicon.

A PayBox connected to a Bank acts as a deposit detector and outputs a signal if a player inserts a set amount of credits, which will go into the Bank.

A Computer connected to a Bank can wirelessly receive credits from other Computer-connected Banks using the Credit instruction. The sending Bank must be locked by the same player as the Computer. See the "Programming" page for more details.

Sell a Bank to obtain all credits inside at once.
bank.rawBody:
Banks are storage boxes for credits.

Left-clicking on a Bank will deposit 100 credits for the player who locked it, or 25 Credits
for any other player. Right-clicking withdraws 100 credits for the player who locked it.

Signal a Bank through Mode 0 Polysilicon to eject a Credit bag of the amount signaled. Note that 
the Polysilicon must be locked by the same player who locked the Bank. Credit bags can also be
inserted into the Bank on contact, albeit with a 4 credit penalty.

Signal a Bank directly to output the credit amount through Mode 3 Polysilicon.

A PayBox connected to a Bank acts as a deposit detector and outputs a signal if a player inserts 
a set amount of credits, which will go into the Bank.

A Computer connected to a Bank can wirelessly receive credits from other Computer-connected Banks 
using the Credit instruction. The sending Bank must be locked by the same player as the Computer.
See the "Programming" page for more details.

Sell a Bank to obtain all credits inside at once.

ore.title: Ore
body: Ores must be refined by attaching them to an unpowered Refinery, or inserting into a powered Refinery.
ore.rawBody:
Ores must be refined by attaching them to an unpowered Refinery, or inserting into a 
powered Refinery.

refinery.title: Refinery
body: A Refinery turns ores into valuable materials. Refineries will slowly process any ore attached to them, but if powered, can almost instantly process ores inserted into it.
refinery.rawBody:
A Refinery turns ores into valuable materials. Refineries will slowly process any ore
attached to them, but if powered, can almost instantly process ores inserted into it.

warpgate.title: WarpGate
body:
WarpGates transport players to a corresponding WarpGate on the other server. Factoriable materials (such as Wood) and mineral resources (such as Protalium) can also be sent through if they are unwelded. Parts sent through a WarpGate quickly despawn if not dragged or inserted into a Crate.

Use the Hammer's Config tool to set the WarpGate's address. To dial the WarpGate, power it and use attached Nodes of each number to enter the 6-digit destination address. If the connection is successful, the WarpGate will open and allow travel. The WarpGate on the opposite side does not require power and cannot be re-entered until the wormhole closes. WarpGates will close if disconnected from power or if nothing is sent through for 30 seconds.

If the WarpGate is blocked on both sides by a large part, any incoming items will be vaporized.

WarpGates set to the same address of another in the same server will eventually reset themselves to a random address.

WarpGates on the Space Server require more advanced materials.

materials (such as Wood) and mineral resources (such as Protalium) can also be sent through if

into a Crate.

footerData.name: Requires (Space Server)
footerData.desc: Lirvanite, Eridanium, Uranium, Silicon, Gold, Abantium
